sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a precipitation reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the precipitation reaction between aqueous solutions of sodium sulfate and barium chloride, given the following balanced chemical equation:

Na2SO4(aq) + BaCl2(aq) → 2NaCl(aq) + BaSO4(s)

The enthalpies of formation values for Na2SO4(aq), BaCl2(aq), NaCl(aq), and BaSO4(s) are -1389.9 kJ/mol, -858.8 kJ/mol, -407.3 kJ/mol, and -1477.2 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of NaCl(aq) and 1 mole of BaSO4(s). For the reactants, we have 1 mole of Na2SO4(aq) and 1 mole of BaCl2(aq).

ΔH_reaction = [(2 × -407.3) + (-1477.2)] - [(-1389.9) + (-858.8)]

ΔH_reaction = [(-814.6) + (-1477.2)] - [(-1389.9) + (-858.8)]

ΔH_reaction = (-2291.8) - (-2248.7)

ΔH_reaction = -43.1 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the precipitation reaction between aqueous solutions of sodium sulfate and barium chloride is -43.1 kJ/mol.
